comments.commentBody:
What about the chances of a serious 3-ring circus in Tampa? How far out of it does Romney have to seem to be before the party makes a change at the conv?

Worse, what if this was the plan all along? Let Romney, or whoever, "win" the primary, and deal with the resulting fallout from having to pretend to be rabidly right-wing. Let Romney struggle with unifying the base and moderates, let him stumble along, floundering, giving the Obama camp a flase sense of complacency, get deep into the messaging for running against Romney. Then...

BAM, Jeb Bush or whoever steps in, gets the nod at the convention. They keep Romney on as Veep for taking one for the team, and to avoid the "GOP is tearing itself apart" meme. Now they've got the nominee most conservatives have wanted all along, without having them damage their credibility in the hilarious GOP primary process; and the Obama campaign has to change gears and start running against a guy(or gal) they've given no thought to yet. There will be a huge amount of awareness, media, and 'enthusiasm' based sheerly on the dramatics of the situation, a "wave."

"There will be a huge amount of awareness, media, and 'enthusiasm' based sheerly on the dramatics of the situation, a "wave.""

C, it's an interesting scenario, but I simply cannot see a huge wave of enthusiasm coming from the Republican voters on behalf of a man they never even nominated. I think an awful lot of the Republican voter base would be deeply insulted by that, and rightly so.

I have a question.
Lets say Obama continues to be favored 70/30 to win right through the GOP convention. And Mitt gets zero bump from his VP pick....I don't think he can actually, from the slate of potentials.
snore city.
Would the race be effectively over at the end of August?
The only uncertainty that remains in the model (besides Monte Carlo) is turnout.
And not GOP turnout, because that is already at max.
The race is dependent on dem turnout.

So what happens if it ends early?

More and more, pollsters are moving away from weighting to PID. It just isn't reliable, and nobody ever knows the 'true' D/R/I of the electorate so the pollster can't weight to the 'true' situation. Conservative criticism of "oversampling" is irrelevant if there's no PID weighting.

Pollsters like PPP weight to stable things like age, race, gender, and income. As far as Party ID, the sample is what it is. Any deficiency along those lines are eliminated in the weighting to other things (age, race, cell, gender, etc.).

Still, it's largely pointless to explain these things, because the conservatives that bellow the loudest about "oversampling" do not have any idea what weighting is, much less how it is applied.

It's really odd that no conservative pollster is showing Romney with enough EV to win. I guess that even the conservative pollsters are "oversampling" Democrats, right?
sirious:   "Conservative pollsters" is an oxymoron. I mean, you can't be sirious.

Insidious Pall wrote:
"Conservative pollsters" is an oxymoron".

True. There are no pollsters out there that conservatives seem to trust. They will believe in whichever pollster says what they want to hear, and that pollster will instantly be immensely credible. The same pollster will be worthless the moment that they show figures that conservatives don't want to see. And they will claim that they never took that pollster seriously. It will all change if the pollster once again supports their pre-conceived notions, too.

If you were around during the 2008 538 ordeal, you may recall conservatives rejecting Rasmussen as "in the tank" for Obama during the final weeks. Now, he's "the most accurate". And even Rasmussen's EV projections aren't showing this wild Romney lead that every conservative here seems to unquestioningly believe in as fact.

And yet another installment in the dem oversampling screechathon.

http://hotair.com/archives/2012/08/02/new-pew-poll-obama-wins-by-10-if-d...

"That’s 43.5D/24.5R/32I, or D+19. The 2008 presidential exit poll, in a big blue year, was D+7. "
hey, AllahP.....this is 2012, not 2008.

@Jim Steinberg

Good question!

Perhaps it is just that too many people cannot remember much past the end of last week?

The Republican Convention will be too right wing to help Romney, and then Obama will destroy him in the debates.

There will certainly be a deluge of dishonest attack adds, but Obama can't be swift boated, and it will be hard to make a case for Romney being Presidential, when all he really has left is his hair.

Romney's only hope is for a disaster, or that the economy gets worse.

And Obama is not Carter. Besides the economy, Carter also had the Iranian hostage crisis weighing him down. Without that crisis, and the failed rescue mission, Carter may have won.
God helps those who help themsleves, sir.  You should probably look into the housing crisis in a bit more depth.  It seems that your understanding could be a bit more informed.
Not for nothing, but all Democrats who own calendars would be thrilled for everyone who supports Romney to vote for him on November 7th...

It wasn't the GOP actors that got us in to this mess.  It was the Clinton era democrats that forced mortgage lenders to lend money to individuals that couldn't afford homes.  The only solution to our demise is a vote for Mitt Romney on November 7th.  God help us all!

here Nate, let me help Allahpundit out with his maths.
New Pew poll: Obama wins by 10 if Democrats lead in turnout this year by, um, 19 points
Aug 2, 2012 9:57 PM by Allahpundit
the difference in turnout between the 2008 and 2010 elections is 56.8 - 37.8 or....EXACTLY 19 points!

lol.

The odds are probably that high in any Presidential election where a candidate is very unpopular in isolated parts of the country and reasonably well-liked (but not fanatically so) everywhere else. Every man, woman, child, dog, pig and sparrow, plus the ghost of John C. Calhoun, will be turning out in South Carolina to vote against President Obama. But at the end of the day, that matters a lot less than modestly pro-Obama turnout in California and New York and Ohio.

Our democracy made it through the 2000 election, where the popular vote loser won an electoral college victory when the Supreme Court stepped in to stop an ongoing recount.  Given that, I don't see that any of the scenarios you mention would totally delegitimize our democracy.  (In addition, I have to believe that there's a lot of overlap between the recount scenarios and the scenarios where one candidate wins the electoral vote while the other wins the popular vote.)

I agree that the Republicans will lose their minds if Obama wins despite losing the popular vote... but we should keep in mind that it happened in 2000 and they were fine with it then.

I believe that's the 4th time it's happened in history overall (3 times in the 1800s!)

Meanwhile, the "Scenario Analysis" continues to show steadily increasing odds of a result that totally delegitimizes our democracy. The model seems to put the chances of an electoral college tie, a recount, or one candidate's winning the popular vote but losing the electoral college at about 1 in 8. (I'm not sure how a recount's compatibility with the other scenarios affects the figure -- the model would need to divide "recount" into subcategories.) Are the odds of electoral catastrophe this high every time an election is reasonably close?

Comparing a non presidential year to a presidential year is pure silliness.

The unfortunate truth is that a lot of the Democratic Party's core voters don't vote in off year elections.

A lot of the people who didn't bother voting in 2010 will be out this time around.

Especially as they learn more and more about what a terrible President Mitt Romney would be.

No sane middle class person is going to vote for their own $2000+ tax increase so Romney & Trump can get a huge tax cut!

ahh, the old gang is getting back together. Between Bart D and Peter K, we have fervent anti-Obama acolytes recycling the same scrutiny-destroyed assertions as in 2008. I won't repeat what others have done in effective rebuttal, but will only add that today, if you do a SIMPLE average of all 34 NON-internet, NON-robocall pollsters (again, those that call cellphones are the ones considered credible enough to put in 538's consensus for the simple reason that a poll missing 50% of the population is not credible scientifically), here's what you get today, August 3.

Obama 48.6%
Romney 44.1%

That is almost exactly in line with Nate's adjusted, crunched, state polled # of Obama leading by 3.6%, done before the strong Ohio, Florida and PA polls.

It is fascinating to wonder just how MANY different pollsters the GOP faithful on this site can attack. Wall Street Jorunal? Pew? Bloomberg? Ipsos? Reuters? etc, Etc...Man, Obama's forces must be spending 1/2 of their $ corrupting MSM pollsters. We only have to account for Rasmussen and his ludicrous +8 lean for Romney as of today.

mikeyz, look upthread a bit and you'll see someone commenting on the idea of "conservative pollsters" as an oxymoron.

Not sure that's a joke, but the truth of the situation is that many conservatives view truth and fact in the world purely on the basis of how it lines up with their ideology. If it doesn't tell them what they want to hear, it's a lie. Period. If the sources are accredited and verified by a wide variety of institutions, that means it's not just a lie, it's a CONSPIRACY OF LIES.

Nate:

Subtracting your 3.8% Democrat house effect from Pew does not even begin to account for Pew putting their thumb on the scale to the extent that Dem voters have a 19% advantage over the GOP.

Over the past couple weeks, these Democrat media pollsters are playing ridiculously transparent games with their consumers...and your model.

The parties were tied in the 2010 vote and the Dems will be very fortunate to have a 2 point advantage over the GOP in partisan turnout in 2012. If you use the generous weighting of D+2, Obama is losing by 7 points in this Pew propaganda poll.
Nate's being nice, the Mittster is toast.

Our morass is due to Republican obstructionism in Congress. Jobs bill? Filibuster. Tax cut? Filibuster. Infrastructure bill? Filibuster. Limit jobs outsourcing? Filibuster.

How can someone fail when all of their programs are blocked. I'd say Republican obstructionism has failed. Just look at the polling results - the radicalization of the right is rotting the party from the inside out.
oh please, sounds like you read off of a cue card from Reince Preibus.
Kudos on spell checking morass. F minus on your 'facts'

I think President Obama is a charming man, but his ideas on running the country have failed. His jobs board, headed by Immelt, hasn't met in 6 months. Obviously, his priorities are not on an economic recovery. If he wins, I will be shocked that we Americans are so willing to continue in this morass due to his winning smile, sexy voice and deceptive rhetoric.

I don't think you understand how "Nat" runs his model.
I believe he calculates the pollsters' house effects irrespective of the LV/RV difference.
That is, the house effects are calculated by comparing various Registered Voter polls with one another (and by comparing the various Likely Voter polls). That's isolating variables, comparing apples to apples.
Similarly, he calculates LV/RV effects by comparing the same polls' LV and RV models, and calculates an adjustment for that effect.
So, once he has the polls' house effects calculated (and re-calculated…), he adjusts the polls for house effects. He then adjusts the Registered Voter polls to come up with a prediction of how the Likely Voters are going to vote.
If Nate were prone to making the kind of glaring error that you apparently think he makes, he would never have garnered the obsessive following that he's earned over the last four years.

In regards to The Artist Formerly, you say you "believe [Nat] calculates the pollster's house effects irrespective of the LV/RV difference". If that is true, then I stand corrected - but that is a big if, and you don't seem to be sure .

And I do have a great deal of respect to Nat - that is why I rasie this thought.

I agree that this poll may be an outliner. I understand the reasoning for the 3.8 per cent slant in favor of Obama/Democrats, but question the addition of the additional 2 per cent for the use of registered voters instead of likely voters. IF one of the reasons for the 3.8 slant in favor of Obama/Democrats IS because of the use of registered instead of likely voters, it would be unfair to count it a second time. Of course, if the Pew Poll used registered voters for the first time in this last poll, I would agree with Nat.

I also believe that, as you approach the election, the difference between registered and likely voters is minimized as all are energized. But this more my speculation, and I will leave it to Nat to correct me.

thanks for sharing the link for Gil Scott-Heron's telling indictment of nostalgia in this country. It's the tea partiers who are nostalgic for a cartoonized history which the GOP shares for this era of muskets and powdered wigs. I wish the right would just come clean and admit this....
Romney's campaign slogan should read "backwards".
Thanks so much for the Gil Scott-Heron,from another era when things started getting rough. I must say though that this is a first having Gil Scott-Heron in the commentary of a Paul Krugman column.

It's never a good idea to give in to extortionists, but that's the game the GOP has been playing with some success, here in Calif, since they've put themselves into semi-permanent minority status. So I expect to see more of the same as far as the eye can see. Unless, of course, they succeed in doing nationally what they're not able to do here - run an extremely wealthy person for chief executive (or senate). Of course if they're a B-movie celebrity, that's a different story out here.

Gil Scott-Heron had a take on this shortly after Reagan was elected POTUS.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=56ipWM3DWe4
Whoever posted the clip, however, left out Gil's riff about Reagan representing "nostalgia" or, as he went on to pronounce it, "NO!-stalgia" - those fed up with the push for "civil rights, women's rights, gay rights - it's all wrong! You give 'em an inch, and they want full equality!" he declared (or something like that), channeling his inner Archie Bunker. That was 1981 and we have the party of NO!-stalgia more than ever. Same issues, too.

But rest assured, if Frat Boy is elected and has a sympathetic congress, deficits won't matter, once again. Of course, they'll be caused by increased military spending and more tax cuts, against which more safety net programs will have to be cut or, like Social Security and Medicare, "remodeled" - even though deficits won't be important. We'll be told it's what will get the country going again. And they'll only be partly wrong then.

This topic is mysterious to me as well, although I know my mom was sorry to see me go a bit before I graduated high school in 1969. I will admit I worried about my son in high school ever making it in the outside world.

But then he turned 17, and became a sensible, rational human being. He had serious questions and thoughts about the world. He was able to connect the things he was doing in class to the real world. It was such a thrill to think that I was not going to have to worry about either him or the world when he would be turned out into in the next year.

I was looked on in our rural area as a terrible mom for discouraging him to apply to schools too close. We wanted to be sure that he participated in life on campus, and did not want him able to come home often. (Christmas, Thanksgiving, between quarters was good enough.)

But what a thrill to be able to send him off with confidence! And how nice to know that he didn't have to call or email us constantly, knowing of course that he could have. I think my husband and I have both gained in self esteem to know that we had raised such a competent young man.

His sister may never leave home, at least not probably until late in her 20's or after. She will not have the skills before then. And that's OK too.

As a parent, I have always enjoyed each developmental stage more than the one before. And I guess I still do, even when a child is living 2000 miles away!

We are like kids with toys in our uncritical embrace of technological innovation.  We don't think about downsides and long-term consequences.  In addition to the issues raised here about intrusive and anonymous monitoring, technology I think is adding to the divisions in our community along economic lines, as not everybody can afford to upgrade constantly to whatever level of technology is currently being required to be part of the mainstream.  I was also interested to read a comment by a computer programmer, I think it was, on the subject of the Knight Capital trading problems, that our systems have become too complicated.  We have 2001: A Space Odyssey's HAL to remind us that we might want to rethink relinquishing so much control to machines.

Why would you not be biking in SF just because you are 79. I am 78 and ride with several people who are in their 80s. We ride the hills around Newcastle and Auburn, and into El Dorado County.

What do you mean "if you are young?" You do not have to be in your 30s to ride bike. Just a good bike and a good set of gears and we are off.

I'm under someone else's account. I'm Sara.

That out of the way...

I think you may have taken the quote you cited too literally. He's certainly not saying that you ARE the sole author of your destiny, but that the perspective of being such can push you toward success. You will then, in time, look back and understand just how partial this notion is. Sure, it's possible to regularly reflect on our interdependence and even show gratitude for it. But I believe Mr. Brooks was simply reflecting on what is usually the case for achievers.

It may be the case that the prescriptive language - his advice - is mixed up here with the descriptive - the observations on aging. In fact, that's exactly what's happening. It's both lovely and totally sloppy - he's waxing poetic, after all.

That said, if people are able to push buoyantly "forward" with their individual goals while also remaining mindful of their reliance in a larger ecosystem, I think that everyone would, indeed, be better off (it sounds a lot like harmony, a very undervalued idea nowadays).

Perhaps Mr. Brooks is being overly deterministic about these stages of aging and simply not giving the young credit for being able to accommodate a broader view (one that might make the world a far kinder, better place). If it's when we're young that we're so radically open, we might as well begin to see ourselves part of the bigger picture - a team! - even as we grab the Olympic torch and count our successes (fingers crossed!).

"You should regard yourself as the sole author of all your future achievements ..."?

Really, David? I'm guessing that you're trying for some humor in this column, or I hope you are, but this line throws me into "confusion."

Consider the nature of time: if the letter writer is a beneficiary of past successes, then by logical construction that writer cannot be the sole author of future achievements. Physics being physics, and quantum nature being quantum nature, that's just the way it works.

Thing is, Mr. Brooks, since I was a soldier a long time ago I've listened to a few souls from my war assert that pretty much that their survival was their own rough and tough doing. But as you rightfully observe, we're all beneficiaries.

You might argue that there's a difference between war and regular life; I assert, au contraire! Not so! None of us, as Donne teaches, is an island. Mitt Romney didn't get where he is because he did it, nor his family because they did it, nor this nation because we did it. We do things in a web of life.

To ignore that is to risk the wrath of the little gods, and as Greeks recognized, and Nietzshe rightfully observes their is nothing new since the Greeks, the wrath of the gods for pride and hubris is the fall. Achilles beat Hector all on his own.

But his own heel tendon destroyed him.

It's hard to argue against Mr Rhoden's choice of Jesse Owens as the greatest Oympian. But I find myself wondering about this American obsession for naming the greatest xyz in very conceivable area of public life.  Once you do that, then you have a bunch of also-rans, like Jim Thorpe and Carl Lewis. Guys who totally dominated the Olympic games when they were in their prime as athletes. Perhaps it is our obsession with winning, and thinking that we are the best in the world.

Does it matter? Jesse Owens was and is in a class by himself.
Michael Phelps is the best swimmer in history. I suspect that neither man, given a chance to voice an opinion, would vote for himself as
"the greatest Olympic athlete ever". I happen to agree with Mr. Rhoden's analysis, if such distinctions need to be made. But again I say, "Does it matter?"
There is no greatest Olympian. This is The Matrix 101: There is no spoon.

This Olympics coverage felt like the USA Show, with a smattering of Russians thrown in for filler.
